title: JavaScript & Node.js Fundamentals
description: From the birth of JavaScript in '95 to the evolution of Node.js - History, syntax, and modern best practices

slides.title: JavaScript & Node.js
slides.subtitle: History, Evolution, and Complete Guide
slides.description: From Brendan Eich (1995) to Node.js 25 (2025) - 30 years of continuous evolution
slides.ironicClosing: JavaScript: born in 10 days, still here after 30 years. Not bad for a prototype.

slides.title: üìú The History of JavaScript
paragraphs: 1995: Brendan Eich creates JavaScript in 10 days for Netscape
2009: ES5 - JSON, Array methods, strict mode
2009: Ryan Dahl creates Node.js - JavaScript steps out of the browser
2015: ES6/ES2015 - Revolution: let/const, arrow functions, classes, modules
2016-2024: Annual releases ES - Async/await, optional chaining, top-level await
2025: Node.js 25 - V8 14.1, optimized performance, native WebAssembly
Today: #1 most used language (GitHub), runtime everywhere (browser, server, IoT)
slides.ironicClosing: From 'toy language' to a pillar of the web. Redemption arc complete.

slides.title: üöÄ Evolution of Node.js
paragraphs: 2009: Node.js 0.x - Ryan Dahl, based on V8 Chrome
2011: npm becomes the standard package manager
2015: Fork io.js, then merge ‚Üí Node.js 4.0 (first LTS)
2022: Node.js 18 - Native Fetch API, Test runner
slides.ironicClosing: Node.js: from experiment to enterprise standard. JavaScript rules everywhere.

slides.title: Current Node.js Versions (2025)
paragraphs: ‚Ä¢ Perfect for: enterprise production, critical systems
‚Ä¢ Only security fixes, end of support near
slides.ironicClosing: Production? Use LTS. Feeling like living dangerously? Try Current.

slides.title: Why JavaScript/Node.js?
paragraphs: Everywhere: Browser, server, desktop (Electron), mobile (React Native), IoT
Performance: V8 engine (Chrome) compiles to native code, incredible speed
Ecosystem: npm has 2.5+ million packages. Everything has already been done.
Native Async: Event loop, non-blocking I/O, perfect for I/O intensive
Community: The largest in the world, tutorials everywhere, stack overflow full
Used by: Netflix, LinkedIn, PayPal, NASA, Uber, Microsoft, Amazon
slides.ironicClosing: If you have to learn just one language in 2025, learn JavaScript. The end.

slides.title: Variabili & Tipi
slides.subtitle: let, const, var and the 7 JavaScript types
slides.description: From var (old) to let/const (modern) - Best practices 2025

slides.title: üíª Variables: let vs const vs var
slides.explanation: const is default. let only if you reassign. var is legacy, always avoid.

slides.title: üíª The 7 Primitive Types
slides.explanation: 7 primitives + Object. typeof to check the type.

slides.title: üíª Type Coercion & Conversions
slides.explanation: JavaScript automatically converts types. Use === to avoid surprises.

slides.title: Truthy and Falsy Values
slides.ironicClosing: An empty array is truthy. [] == false is true. JavaScript logic. Don't ask.

slides.title: üíª Template Literals (Backticks)
slides.explanation: Backticks (`) allow interpolation. Always use these, not concatenation.

slides.title: üíª Destructuring Assignment
slides.explanation: Destructuring extracts values from arrays/objects. Elegant and widely used.

slides.title: üíª Arithmetic Operators & Assignment

code.snippet:
// Aritmetici base
let a = 10, b = 3;
console.log(a + b);   // 13
console.log(a - b);   // 7
console.log(a * b);   // 30
console.log(a / b);   // 3.333...
console.log(a % b);   // 1 (modulo)
console.log(a ** b);  // 1000 (potenza, ES2016)

// Increment/Decrement
let x = 5;
x++;      // x = 6 (postfix)
++x;      // x = 7 (prefix)
x--;      // x = 6

// Assignment composti
let n = 10;
n += 5;   // n = 15
n -= 3;   // n = 12
n *= 2;   // n = 24
n /= 4;   // n = 6
n %= 4;   // n = 2
n **= 3;  // n = 8

slides.explanation: Standard operators + power (**) introduced in ES2016.

slides.title: üíª Comparison & Logic
slides.explanation: === is sacred. ?? is better than || for default values (0 and '' are valid).

slides.title: üíª Ternary & Optional Chaining
slides.explanation: Optional chaining (?.) prevents errors on null/undefined. Essential.

slides.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Common Errors
slides.ironicClosing: JavaScript forgives a lot. Too much. Use strict mode and linters for safety.

slides.title: Functions
slides.subtitle: Declaration, Expression, Arrow, Callbacks
slides.description: All modern syntax for defining functions

slides.title: üíª Function Declaration vs Expression
slides.explanation: Declaration is hoisted (available first), Expression is not. You prefer Expression.

slides.title: üíª Arrow Functions (ES6)
slides.explanation: Arrow functions: compact syntax, no this binding. Preferred in modern code.

slides.title: üíª Parameters: Default, Rest, Spread
slides.explanation: ... as rest gathers arguments, as spread expands arrays/objects.

slides.title: üíª Callbacks & Higher-Order Functions
slides.explanation: Callbacks are everywhere in JavaScript. Array methods use them extensively.

slides.title: üíª IIFE & Closures
slides.explanation: Closures allow encapsulation. The let in loop creates an automatic closure.

slides.title: this Keyword (Advanced)
paragraphs: Arrow functions do NOT have their own this (they inherit from the external scope)
Regular functions - this depends on how they are called
‚Ä¢ Use arrow functions for callbacks (no this problem)
‚Ä¢ Use regular functions for object methods
‚Ä¢ Avoid this if possible (functional programming style)
slides.ironicClosing: this in JavaScript: an infinite source of bugs. Arrow functions save your life.

slides.title: Array & Objects
slides.subtitle: Fundamental Data Structures
slides.description: Modern array methods and object manipulation

slides.title: üíª Array: Creation & Basic Methods
slides.explanation: JavaScript arrays are dynamic. push/pop for the end, shift/unshift for the beginning.

slides.title: üíª Array: Map, Filter, Reduce
slides.explanation: map/filter/reduce are the heart of functional programming in JS.

slides.title: üíª Array: Modern Methods
slides.explanation: flat/flatMap for nested arrays, at() for negative access. Very handy.

slides.title: üíª Objects: Creation & Manipulation
slides.explanation: Object literal is the basic syntax. Shorthand properties are modern and clean.

slides.title: üíª Metodi dell'oggetto (Statici)
slides.explanation: Object.entries for iteration. Spread {...} for cloning/merging. Preferred over assign.

slides.title: üíª JSON: Serialization
slides.explanation: JSON.stringify/parse for serialization. Node.js 25 has 2x better performance.

slides.title: Async & Promises
slides.subtitle: Callbacks, Promises, Async/Await
slides.description: Modern asynchronous management - From callback hell to async/await

slides.title: Asynchronous JavaScript: Why?
paragraphs: JavaScript executes code in a single thread. Blocking I/O operations (network, file) would halt everything.
Node.js delegates I/O operations to the operating system, continues execution, and receives callbacks when ready.
‚Ä¢ Callbacks (2009): Functions passed as arguments ‚Üí callback hell
‚Ä¢ Promises (ES6/2015): Objects that represent future completion ‚Üí chainable
‚Ä¢ Async/Await (ES2017): Syntactic sugar on Promises ‚Üí synchronous-like code
Today (2025): Async/await is standard. Promises when fine control is needed.
slides.ironicClosing: Event loop: magic that makes JavaScript seem multi-threaded. Spoiler: it isn't.

slides.title: üíª Callbacks: The Old Way
slides.explanation: Callbacks work but create callback hell. Promises solve the problem.

slides.title: üíª Promises: Creation & Usage
slides.explanation: Promise has 3 states: pending, fulfilled, rejected. then/catch to handle.

slides.title: üíª Promise Chaining & Error Handling
slides.explanation: then() returns a Promise, allowing chaining. catch() catches errors anywhere.

slides.title: üíª Promise Combinator Methods
slides.explanation: all/allSettled/race/any to combine Promises. allSettled is very useful.

slides.title: üíª Async/Await: Modern Syntax
slides.explanation: async/await makes asynchronous code readable like synchronous code. Always use try/catch.

slides.title: üíª Top-Level Await (ES2022)
slides.explanation: Top-level await in ES modules. No async function wrapper. Node.js 14+.

slides.title: ES6+ Features
slides.subtitle: Modules, Classes, Symbols, Iterators
slides.description: Modern JavaScript features from ES6 onwards

slides.title: üíª ES Modules: Import/Export
slides.explanation: ES modules are standard. Node.js: .mjs or "type": "module" in package.json.

slides.title: üíª Classes (ES6)
slides.explanation: Classes are syntax sugar over prototypes. They use constructors, methods, getters/setters.

slides.title: üíª Inheritance & Private Fields
slides.explanation: extends for inheritance, super for parent. # for private fields (ES2022).

slides.title: üíª Symbols & Iterators
slides.explanation: Symbol for unique identifiers. Iterator protocol for iterable objects.

slides.title: üíª Generators (ES6)
slides.explanation: Generators pause execution with yield. Useful for lazy evaluation.

slides.title: üíª Proxy & Reflect (ES6)
slides.explanation: Proxy intercepts operations. Reflect provides reflective APIs. Advanced but powerful.

slides.title: Node.js Basics
slides.subtitle: Server-side JavaScript with Node.js
slides.description: Event loop, core modules, globals, process

slides.title: What is Node.js?
paragraphs: Node.js = JavaScript Runtime based on V8 (Chrome engine)
‚Ä¢ Only for web servers (it's general purpose)
‚Ä¢ Perfect for I/O intensive (API, real-time, microservices)
‚Ä¢ Not optimal for CPU intensive (use worker threads or other languages)
slides.ironicClosing: Node.js: JavaScript everywhere. Browser developers conquering the backend.

slides.title: üíª Global Objects in Node.js
slides.explanation: __dirname/__filename in CommonJS. import.meta in ES modules. process everywhere.

slides.title: üíª Process: Events & Exit
slides.explanation: Process events to manage lifecycle. uncaughtException/unhandledRejection critical.

slides.title: üíª CommonJS vs ES Modules
slides.explanation: CommonJS is legacy but widespread. ES modules are the future. Node.js 22+ supports both.

slides.title: üíª Core Modules: path, url, util
slides.explanation: path for filesystem, url for parsing, util for conversions. Essential core modules.

slides.title: üíª Events: EventEmitter
slides.explanation: EventEmitter is the pub/sub pattern of Node.js. Many core modules use it.

slides.title: NPM: Node Package Manager
paragraphs: ‚Ä¢ CLI to install, publish, manage dependencies
slides.ironicClosing: npm install: the most used command after console.log. 2.5M packages and growing.

slides.title: üíª NPM: Essential Commands

code.snippet:
# Inizializzare progetto
npm init                    # Wizard interattivo
npm init -y                 # Default (skip domande)

# Installare packages
npm install express         # Dipendenza production
npm install -D jest         # Dev dependency
npm install lodash@4.17.21  # Versione specifica
npm install                 # Installa da package.json

# Disinstallare
npm uninstall express

# Update
npm update                  # Update minori
npm outdated                # Mostra outdated
npm install lodash@latest   # Latest version

# Scripts (definiti in package.json)
npm run build
npm test                    # Shortcut per npm run test
npm start                   # Shortcut per npm run start

# Global packages
npm install -g nodemon      # Globale
npm list -g --depth=0       # Lista globali

slides.explanation: npm install is basic. -D for dev deps. Scripts in package.json automate tasks.

slides.title: üíª package.json: Structure
slides.explanation: package.json is the heart of the project. Scripts automate. Engines specify Node.js.

slides.title: Semantic Versioning (SemVer)
paragraphs: Best practice: Use ^ to balance updates and stability
slides.ironicClosing: SemVer: perfect theory. Practice: breaking changes even in minor. Trust but verify.

slides.title: üíª Create & Publish Package

code.snippet:
# 1. Creare account npm
npm adduser

# 2. Preparare package.json
# - name unico (scoped: @username/package)
# - version (SemVer)
# - main (entry point)
# - files (cosa includere)

# package.json esempio
{
  "name": "@myusername/my-package",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "main": "index.js",
  "files": ["dist", "README.md"],
  "keywords": ["utility", "helper"],
  "repository": "github:user/repo"
}

# 3. Test locale
npm link                    # Nella dir del package
npm link @myusername/my-package  # Nel progetto test

# 4. Pubblicare
npm publish --access public  # Per scoped packages
npm version patch            # Bump version
npm publish                  # Update

slides.explanation: npm publish makes the package available to everyone. Scoped (@user/pkg) for namespacing.

slides.title: File System & I/O
slides.subtitle: Reading and writing files with Node.js

slides.title: üíª File System: Sync vs Async
slides.explanation: fs/promises is modern. Always async (do not block the event loop). Sync only for startup.

slides.title: üíª File System: Common Operations
slides.explanation: fs/promises has all the filesystem operations. mkdir recursive creates parent dirs.

slides.title: üíª Streams: Large Efficient Files
slides.explanation: Streams for large files. pipeline() is a modern API. Memory-efficient.

slides.title: üíª Buffer: Dati binari
slides.explanation: Buffer for binary data. Node.js 25 has native Uint8Array.toBase64/toHex.

paragraphs: ‚Ä¢ V8 updated with new JIT optimizations
‚Ä¢ Better error messages with readable stack traces

slides.title: üöÄ Node.js 25 (Current 2025)
slides.ironicClosing: Node.js 25: bleeding edge. For production, LTS. For fun, Current.

slides.title: üíª Built-in Test Runner (Node.js 18+)
slides.explanation: Built-in test runner from Node.js 18. Coverage from 20. Zero dependencies.

slides.title: üíª Native Fetch API (Node.js 18+)
slides.explanation: Native Fetch API from Node.js 18. Same API as the browser. No dependencies.

slides.title: üíª Permission Model (Node.js 20+)
slides.explanation: The permission model limits access to the filesystem/network. Security for untrusted code.

slides.title: üíª Watch Mode (Node.js 18+)

code.snippet:
# Watch mode nativo - auto-restart on file change
node --watch app.js

# Watch con test
node --watch --test

# Watch specifici file
node --watch-path=./src --watch-path=./lib app.js

# Prima di Node.js 18: nodemon necessario
# npm install -g nodemon
# nodemon app.js

# Ora: --watch built-in!
# Risparmio: -1 dependency globale

# package.json script
{
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "node --watch app.js",
    "test:watch": "node --watch --test"
  }
}

# VS Code launch.json
{
  "type": "node",
  "request": "launch",
  "name": "Watch",
  "program": "${workspaceFolder}/app.js",
  "runtimeArgs": ["--watch"]
}

slides.explanation: --watch built-in from Node.js 18. No nodemon needed. Improved dev experience.
